name: maleic anhydride production by catalytic oxidation of benzene | heat, from steam, in chemical industry | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/28108/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of maleic anhydride, with steam as by product. Maleic anhydride is an organic chemical compound which consists of white crystalline flakes that have a pungent, acrid odor. It is soluble in acetone, ether and petroleum. According to (IPPC Chemicals, 2002), maleic anhydride is used to produce unsaturated polyesters, fumaric and maleic acid, and is also used as an intermediate for the production of pesticides.;In 1991, one-third of maleic acid production capacity was based on benzene oxidation and the rest was from the oxidation of butane and butene. Notably, the n-butane pathway is classified as the most economic raw material for maleic anhydride production. Thereofe, n-butane is the preferred pathway in the US and Japan, while existing facilities were converted to accept C4 feedstocks instead of benzene. Major manufacturers include Lonza, Bayer and Huntsman, among many others (Wells, 1999).;Maleic anhydride reacts with water to form maleic acid and will dimerize in the presence of UV light. A decomposition/polymerization reaction will occur with alkalis at elevated temperatures. It is a skin, eye and mucous membrane irritant (Wells, 1999).;In this dataset, the raw material inputs, and process-specific material exchanges, are modelled with a generic stoichiometry-based tool, using literature or estimated yields. The emissions are modelled with a default value, which is estimated based on losses, unreacted chemicals, among others. At the same time, the energy consumption is based on data from personal communications and literature sources. Finally, the auxiliary (i.e., cooling water and infrastructure) exchanges are modelled with a default value based on industry data from literature sources. For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure.;References:;Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.;Personal communication, Giovanni.Montiglio, Lonza, May 2003;G. Margaret Wells, “Handbook of Petrochemicals and Processes”, 2nd edition, Ashgate, 1999

The activity starts when the raw materials enter the process.

This activity ends with the production of maleic anhydride, with steam as a byproduct. All precursors and infrastructure are included.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The time period spans from the earliest year from which at least one of the input values was obtained until 2022, but overall form the most realistic picture of the production. Besides, the activity is partly generated, in terms of material inputs and outputs, based on a generic stoichiometry-based model, using literature or estimated yields, which does not expect to change over time.;The source of information for the heat and electricity inputs is literature data (from 2007) for the specific technology. Finally, the main source of information for the values for water (process and cooling), nitrogen, chemical factory is industry data from the GENDORF Chemical Park. The values are a 5-year average of data from 2015-2019 published by the GENDORF Chemical Park, which is based in Germany and produced an average of tonnes of chemical substances in the years 2462760. The end time period is therefore set based on the years from Gendorf reference.;For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure and in the comments of the exchanges.;References:;Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59-67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled at the Global level. The main material inputs and outputs of this activity are generated with on a generic stoichiometry-based model, using literature or estimated yields. Furthermore, the source of information for the heat and electricity inputs is literature data for the specific technology. Finally, the main source of information for the values for water (process and cooling), nitrogen, chemical factory is industry data from the GENDORF Chemical Park, which is based in Germany and produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances in the years 2015-2019. For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure.;The dataset could also be considered as not geography-specific, and thus, valid for a broader geographical coverage.;References:;Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59-67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989)
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Air is preheated and compressed and mixed with benzene over a catalyst Heat from the strongly process exothermic serves to produce steam (molten salts are used to remove heat). The exit gases contain maleic anhydride, carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide and traces of aromatics. 50-60% of the anhydride is obtained directly from the reaction gas mixture. The remainder is recovered in the form of maleic acid. The maleic acid is then converted to anhydride via dehydration, usually by distillation with xylene (Falcke et al., 2017). Off gases leaving the scrubber are sent to a catalytic incinerator (personal communication Lonza).;C6H6 + 4½ O2 -> C4H2O3 + H2O + 2 CO2;The reaction occurs at slightly elevated pressure and temperatures of 350 – 450 °C and 1.5–2.5 bar with residence times over the catalysts of about 0.1 s and an air excess. The oxidation reaction in modern plants is performed at higher concentrations of benzene in air, reducing the amount of air required by the process. This reduces the amount of electricity needed for the air compressor, which is the larger portion of the overall electricity consumption, according (personal communication Lonza).;Regarding the catalytic system, vanadium oxides are used on different promoters such as phosphorus and the oxides of Fe, Cr, Ti, Co, Ni, Mo (such as V2O5-H3PO4).;In this dataset, a yield of 88% was assumed, according to Wells (1999). The treated exhaust gas contains undreacted benzene and carbon monoxide, and thus, is being combusted. Please note that the catalytic system is not covered.;References:;Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.;G. Margaret Wells, “Handbook of Petrochemicals and Processes”, 2nd edition, Ashgate, 1999;Falcke, Heino, et al. "Best Available Techniques (BAT) reference document for the production of large volume organic chemicals." Publications Office of the European Union: Luxembourg (2017).
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography RER. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Literature data and stoichiometric calculation. This inventory is partially based on a generic model of the production of chemicals. The data generated by this model have been improved with compound-specific data when available. The model of the production of chemicals is using specific industry or literature data wherever possible and more generic data on chemical production processes to fill compound-specific data gaps when necessary. The basic principles of the model have been published in literature (Hischier, 2005). The model has been updated and extended with newly available data from the chemical industry. In the model, unreacted fractions are treated in a waste treatment process, and emissions reported are after a waste treatment process that is included in the scope of this dataset. For volatile reactants, a small level of evaporation is assumed. Solvents and catalysts are mostly recycled in closed-loop systems within the scope of the dataset and reported flows are for losses from this system. The source of information for the heat and electricity inputs is based on personal communication with a manufacturing company (reported in 2007), cross validated with literature data from 1989, for the specific technology. Finally, the main source of information for the values for water (process and cooling), nitrogen, and chemical factory is industry data from the GENDORF Chemical Park. The values are a 5-year average of data from 2015 to 2019 published by the GENDORF Chemical Park, which is based in Germany and produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances in the years 2015-2019. For more information refer to the comments of the exchanges. References: Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59-67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7 Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH. Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989)

exchanges.description:
Highly exothermic production processes, producing steam as a by-product. According to personal communications with Lonza (in 2003), the catalytic oxidation of benzene to maleic anhydride co-generates 6.5 kg of steam per kg of maleic anhydride (Althaus, 2007). At the same time, Chauvel and Lefebvre (1989) reported a value of 4.5 kg of steam per kg of maleic anhydride. We, here, use the most up-to-date value, i.e., 6.5 kg of steam per kg of maleic anhydride, which equals to 17.875 MJ per kg.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Personal communication, Giovanni.Montiglio, Lonza, May 2003
Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989)

flow.name: heat, from steam, in chemical industry
flow.category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/353:Steam and air conditioning supply/3530:Steam and air conditioning supply

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. This value is a 5-year average of data (2011 - 2015) published by the Gendorf factory (Gendorf, 2016, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de), (Gendorf, 2015, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de), (Gendorf, 2014, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de). The amount of water for cooling extracted per kg of chemical substance produced is calculated using literature data published by the Gendorf factory based in Germany, which produces a wide range of chemical substances. The factory produced 1657400 tonnes of chemical substances in the year 2015 (Gendorf, 2016, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de) and 740000 tonnes of intermediate products. The reported amounts of water extracted as groundwater and surface water (river) are assumed to be used entirely for cooling purposes.

flow.name: Water, cooling, unspecified natural origin
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in water

exchanges.description: Calculated losses, based on the boiling point of a chemical, to water or to air. In addition, unreacted chemicals are assumed to go to wastewater treatment, which has a conversion rate in biological treatment of 95% of carbon into carbon dioxide. The remaining 5% are released as emissions to water.

flow.name: Oxygen
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/unspecified

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the industry (Gendorf, 2016, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de). The amount of water released back to the environment consists of the amount of process water treated in the internal WWTP and then released back to the environment and the amount of cooling water released back to the environment.

flow.name: Water
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/unspecified

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The BOD, COD, TOC and BOD5 are calculated based on the amount and type of emissions released to water in the same activity.

flow.name: BOD5, Biological Oxygen Demand
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/unspecified

exchanges.description:
According to personal communications with Lonza (in 2003), the catalytic oxidation of benzene to maleic anhydride requires 0.6 kWh of electricity per kg of maleic anhydride (Althaus, 2007). At the same time, Chauvel and Lefebvre (1989) reported a value of 1.5 kWh of electricity per kg of maleic anhydride. We, here, use the most up-to-date value, i.e., the personal communications with Lonza, in alignment with the heat output source.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Personal communication, Giovanni.Montiglio, Lonza, May 2003
Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989).

exchanges.description: Calculated losses, based on the boiling point of a chemical, to water or to air. flow.name: Carbon dioxide, fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical. References: Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH. Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.

exchanges.description: Calculated to ensure the water balance. In general, in the case of recirculating cooling systems, 77% of the water input evaporates to air. In case of once-through cooling systems, 4% of the water input evaporates to air. The process water has in the chemical industry an average evaporation rate of 20.5%. In the specific case of the Gendorf factory, the calculated evaporation rate based on the data published is 6.3%. This matches the qualitative information, that the majority of the cooling systems in Gendorf are once-through and that the amount of cooling water used is significantly higher than the amount of process water used (Gendorf, 2016, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de).

flow.name: Water
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/unspecified

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. This value is a 5-year average of data (2011 - 2015) published by the Gendorf factory (Gendorf, 2016, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de), (Gendorf, 2015, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de), (Gendorf, 2014, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de). The amount of groundwater and surface water (river) extracted per kg of chemical substance produced is calculated using literature data published by the Gendorf factory based in Germany, which produces a wide range of chemical substances. The factory produced 1657400 tonnes of chemical substances in the year 2015 (Gendorf, 2016, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de) and 740000 tonnes of intermediate products. The amount of groundwater and surface water (river) extracted in the year 2015 was 19950000 tonnes and 21488100 tonnes respectively (Gendorf, 2016, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de).

We, here, use the most up-to-date value, i.e., the personal communications with Lonza, in alignment with the heat output source.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Personal communication, Giovanni.Montiglio, Lonza, May 2003
Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989).

exchanges.description: Calculated losses, based on the boiling point of a chemical, to water or to air. In addition, unreacted chemicals are assumed to go to wastewater treatment, which has a conversion rate in biological treatment of 95% of carbon into carbon dioxide. The remaining 5% are released as emissions to water.

flow.name: Benzene
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/unspecified

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The BOD, COD, TOC and BOD5 are calculated based on the amount and type of emissions released to water in the same activity.

flow.name: TOC, Total Organic Carbon
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/unspecified

exchanges.description: Calculated value based on stoichiometric calculations and literature data. For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure.

flow.name: Oxygen
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in air

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical. References: Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH. Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.

exchanges.description: Calculated losses, based on the boiling point of a chemical, to water or to air. In addition, unreacted chemicals are assumed to go to wastewater treatment, which has a conversion rate in biological treatment of 95% of carbon into carbon dioxide. The remaining 5% are released as emissions to water.

flow.name: Benzene
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
According to personal communications with Lonza (in 2003), the catalytic oxidation of benzene to maleic anhydride requires 0.6 kWh of electricity per kg of maleic anhydride (Althaus, 2007). At the same time, Chauvel and Lefebvre (1989) reported a value of 1.5 kWh of electricity per kg of maleic anhydride. We, here, use the most up-to-date value, i.e., the personal communications with Lonza, in alignment with the heat output source.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Personal communication, Giovanni.Montiglio, Lonza, May 2003
Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989).
